metadata.subject: Collection of articles on Middle East policy and humanitarian intervention

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
Project for the New American Century

relationships.description: Strained diplomatic relationship over Middle East peace process and settlement policies
U.S. ambassador working to shield Israel from UN scrutiny while using pressure for peace process
Leading advocate for humanitarian intervention and genocide prevention in Obama administration

analysis.purpose: Policy analysis and critique of U.S. Middle East foreign policy and humanitarian intervention approaches
analysis.significance: Comprehensive examination of Obama administration's Middle East policy challenges and the rise of humanitarian intervention doctrine

notable_quotes: "If there is indeed still a window of opportunity for a comprehensive Arabâ€“Israeli peace, it may not remain open for long. And if Obama does not try to break the impasse, it is unlikely that his eventual successor will do so."
"How the ICC handles issues concerning the Goldstone Report will be perceived by many in the US as a test for the ICC, as this is a very sensitive matter."
"Kings can have subjects," George F. Kennan once observed, "it is a question whether a republic can."

blackmail_indicators.description: No evidence of blackmail or coercion found in these policy analysis articles

illegal_activity.description: Documents are analytical articles discussing policy matters, not evidence of first-hand illegal activity

details: Multiple articles from major publications analyzing foreign policy
References to media coverage of Middle East conflicts
Discussion of public perception and narrative control

public_knowledge.context: These are published articles from well-known policy journals and newspapers, representing mainstream foreign policy analysis

analysis.summary: This document contains four analytical articles examining U.S. Middle East policy under the Obama administration, focusing on Israeli-Palestinian peace process challenges, U.S. diplomatic efforts at the UN, budget priorities in Afghanistan versus Egypt, and the rise of humanitarian intervention ideology spearheaded by Samantha Power.
